Failed the explanation of energy within seconds... cells do not run on glucose, cells do not run on ketones. Cells use these substrates, including alcohol by directing them to mitochondria. Where the Citric Acid/Krebs Cycle, converts them into ATP + ADP. Adenosine triphosphate and Adenosine diphosphate, these bonds are broken to release energy.

The sluggishness described is best understood by metabolic regulation. For most people who are running with high sugar, the ketone pathway is downregulated. As you transition to ketones, it takes time for the cells to upregulate (upgrade) ketone pathways.

I officially fasted. For A Week!!! Weighing 216 pounds, I knew I would lose weight faster than others but I didn’t expect these results. First of all, I started on a Sunday which is why I’m saying this on a Saturday and crazy stuff happened. I’m always searching this stuff but literally no one has tried this, I’ve only seen stuff on fasting but studies only get technical and say people will give up in a matter of days so they don’t elaborate on it anymore, which sucks because I wanted to know beyond the point of giving up. And others just fake their fasting. So let me tell you what I did. First of all I fasted by not eating a single thing. Only drinking water, and a cup of brisk every time I felt hungry. I bought a 3 liter bottle of brisk since that is all I would trick my body into “consuming” but only allowed myself to drink a cup per day. On Sunday I started off great, didn’t even care. I drank my cup of brisk at night went to sleep and it was easy. Monday came and i started contemplating what to eat. But I stopped myself. I drank my first cup and played video games for hours to distract myself until the day ended. I took naps also and just did whatever to have time pass by. Tuesday I woke up starving with a dry mouth. I felt weak but didn’t care because I expected it. The whole day I spent slouching, being lazy, and not having the energy to do anything or put thought into anything. But I never slept. I couldn’t do anything I enjoyed and was so emotional towards the end of the day. Night came and I was so tired from not sleeping or napping all day that I knocked out. Wednesday comes and something happened I never knew could ever happen. MY BODY SWEAT A TOTAL OF 9 POUNDS!!! I fell asleep and kept waking up for minutes only to fall asleep again for 14 hours straight from 12am - 2pm of Wednesday. I went to sleep 115 pounds and weighed 106 pounds when I woke up! I told everybody I knew but they didn’t think much of it. I showed them my proof and everything yet no one seemed to care. They just kept telling me not to starve myself and eat. But I didn’t want to, I hate not fitting in my clothes so I brushed it off my shoulders. I went to my room and drank my cup of brisk. I did research and you can too if you don’t believe me, studies have proven that people have gone to sleep and have lost a total of 1-7 pounds of water weight. I know it’s water weight and not much will think of it but that’s a huge significance for me in my weight. So I go to sleep at the end of the day and then weirder stuff starts happening the next day. I wake up earlier than usual, I keep sweating but now my body can’t rest. I woke up at 6am and couldn’t sleep for the rest of the day. My body felt so unproductive but not having enough energy I didn’t bother to look for food. I stayed in bed ALL DAY. I was just thinking constantly, looking at the mirror constantly just to see even the slightest of change or improvement. Even trying on outfits and seeing how I fit in them now compared to before. I went to sleep Thursday weighing 104 pounds devastated. I woke up early and sweating still. Now stuff started getting technical. I realized I never drank my cup of brisk and drank two. I weighed my self and saw I was 105! I hated myself. I realized now every ounce of water or brisk I drink I will be able to see on the scale no matter what. I hated myself. I thought I lost progress and thought of a solution. I kept taking naps, doing whatever I could to sleep no matter what. Constantly the thought of self hatred and sleep motivated me to. Hours and hours of naps, Only resolved to one thing I knew would happen. I’m a heavy sweater and maybe it’s due to my weight. So when I sleep I sweat a lot, I woke up very late and weighed my self. It’s now Saturday Morning, 3:52 am and I weight 199.2 POUNDS!!!!! I can’t believe it man. I went to the first video of fasting which is this one and told my story as the video went on. I’m going to be fasting for a month, it feels like hell but I won’t allow myself to go above 200 Pounds ever again. I’ve weighed over 200 pounds for 4 years now! Never again. I’m telling this to people who want to know the results but can’t find them anywhere. I’m going to copy and paste thing comment so I can post it on comments of other videos that might resemble this one for anyone interested. I’m willing to answer to any comments whenever I’m available. Wish me luck, and good luck on fasting!

For people who are interested this was my experience eating nothing for a whole week : first 12 hours were really hard . Couldn't shake the hunger off and was forcing my self to sleep most of the first day . After 24 hours I started to get the hang of it . Urinated alot but didn't poop for the whole duration.  Third day I started noticing feeling really fatigue. Alot of times I found my self almost falling from feeling dizzy whenever I'm walking for a long time . 5th day was feeling OK I had pain in my sides but decided to ignore that . At the 7th day (the day I broke my fast) I literally and physically and mentally could not get out of my own bed and felt as though everything is in slow motion . Had to call my brother and told him to bring vegetable soup and some essential vitamins . My starting weight was 95 KG and my height is around 178 CM . My result was 75 KG after a week . But the thing is after a month from that experience I gained all of my weight even though I didn't eat any fast food or fried food only boiled and BBQ and weighed around 112 KG . Wouldn't recommend it to my worst enemy

This video is semi rediculous... First and most importantly, your body does NOT begin to eat muscles and bone until ALL of your fat stores have been depleted. So, unless you are already skin and bones, you will simply lose fat from your body. Also, your body will start to repair cells that have been damaged by overfeeding, which is a common cause of all kinds of inflammations, including diabetes, non-congenital heart issues, and actually, certain types of cancers. Fasting for 72 hours is actually a very healthy lifestyle for most americans. Unless you're living in a third world country and starving already, your body will not start to eat muscle and bones. Especially when all that fat is just just waiting to be consumed.

Food is a favourite pastime for many, which is convenient because we need it to live. But what would happen to you and your body if you were to completely stop eating food, right now? In the first 6 hours, all is fairly normal. Your body begins to break down glycogen - which stores energy in your body - into glucose, which your cells use as fuel. Around 25% of energy generated this way is used for your brain alone, while the rest goes to muscle tissues and red blood cells. But after about 6 hours this method of energy production halts as the glycogen stores deplete, which can lead to the notorious ‘hangry’ or hungry and angry feeling that many of us know too well.

I can't believe how wrong this video is. The start is good (except the 6hours, it is more like 48), but the rest of the video is just factualy wrong.
One can live on ketones for a long time, but you just need to eat enough fat. I've been doing it for 3 years. The body does not start to break down muscle mass when enough energy (fat) is in the food. Actually, it stimulates growth hormones.
Most have enough energy stored to survice for at least 6 months without food. The body can produce glucose from the stored fat or muscle to feed the brain. People usually die from not having enough salt/magnesium/potassium (electrolytes), but not because of not getting enough calories.

Dear 2015,

This is 2020: the balance of the brain's energy is made up using ketones through gluconegenesis.

So freshmen year I used to stop eating breakfast & lunch. I would be late to school which means I had no time to eat and no time to make lunch. After a few weeks I decided to fully starve myself and not eat any meals because I was going through a tough time. I had also starting working out within that same time. After about 2 weeks of not eating the feeling of hunger completely disappeared and I would never feel hungry. I only ever drank water. I realized some of my friends would notice my eating habits so once in a great while I would munch on something light like a power bar or toast and I survived this way for 3 months. I lost 10 pounds within those months which is quite a bit in my opinion for only 3 months (2 1/2 months maybe I cant quite remember but around 3). My mom had even complimented saying She could tell I was loosing weight. At that moment I only continued my routine until break came along and I lost track and binged ate and since then Ive gained weight. But I didnt gain more weight im at the same amount of pounds I was at before I lost weight. Anyways I don’t recommend starving but I would be hypocritical since im still going through it. My point was hunger lasts for only about 2 weeks before your body suddenly stops reminding you that it wants food. But still once in a great while eat something whether it be one meal a month or maybe toast or something. And drink lots of water.

Some truth, but a ton of bad information. The body does begin to break down protein after 72 hours, but the vast majority of it comes from cannibalized old and/or under performing cells that the body seeks out in an effort to maximize energy stores. In particular cancerous cell tissue is targeted (as everyone’s body produces some cancerous tissue daily that the immune system must deal with). The body can also metabolize fat into a simple sugar (along with some excess proteins) to form sugars which are then used as the make up fuel for the parts of the brain that cannot process ketones. Muscle tissue is the last to be targeted and it takes much longer than three days before any serious kind of muscle tissue degradation occurs. More like 5 to 7, and for some even more, days. Even then the amount is very small. Most heart arrhythmia problems are caused by lack of electrolytes (salt, potassium, magnesium which are vital for proper muscle function), which can be remedied by merely taking a supplement, as well as vitamin issues which can be remedied in the same manner. People all over are regularly doing 7, or 14, or 30, or even 40 day fasts. If unprepared you will have issues, but with some knowledge and preparation it can be done. I've just completed my 1 week water fast! and this was my experience...

Day 1-2: Feeling so hungry that I watch Food Channels on YouTube almost non-stop.
Day 3: Feeling so 'Hangry" my dad yells at me for being mad all the time, which only made me more mad. Also, I felt a few small pains around my stomach a few times, and had gotten 3 random red/purple bruises out of nowhere. (Which is sometimes an effect caused by water fasting).
Day 4: In the middle of the day, I suddenly feel no hunger whatsoever! My stomach stops hurting and I feel a lot more energy. I still mentally wish I could eat and could have a few junk foods but if you were to place something like a pizza in front of me I would not eat it. I feel I have a lot more self control, and even eating something small like a small salad would feel like a lot of food to me.
Day 5-7: Still not feeling hungry whatsoever (only a little bit mentally), unfortunately my bruises haven't disappeared or lessened in color at all so I will need to go to the chemist and see if if I could get something to fix it.

Day 8: I quit my 1 week fasting and I am eating only vegetables for at least 4 days to break my fast.
*Warning*: Do not drink a cup of liquid that is something other than water on the very day that you break your fast (e.g. Thick Vegetable Soup) because 99% of the time, you will feel so much pain because your stomach has not recovered it's former natural amounts of Stomach Acid yet that it needs to digest regular/healthy food again. I had done this, and it felt my rib cage was tearing and I nearly puked and felt I was going to pass out! That's why I recommend that you break your fast slowly over a period of 4 days, with green vegetables like pickles and cucumbers.

So yes, I was very lucky that I didn't experience any severe symptoms from my Water Fasting experience. But I am sure that was because, prior to my first ever Weekly Fasting I had already been growing used to the Fasting experience for at least 2 weeks. For 2 weeks I had fasted for at least 3-4 days per week. It seems as though, most people commenting below had only suddenly started a 7+ day Fasting which will hit you a lot harder than gradually getting used to Fasting.

Furthermore, it was also a lot easier for me to achieve since I am an overweight person so people who are at their regular BMI will (on average) have more unpleasant symptoms occur during a water Fast. But now I will reduce the amount of days that I fast each week because, if you eat too little calories/fast too long... you may loose a lot of weight at first but then your Metabolism will decrease over time (especially after a 4-6 month period of severe diet restriction). And so, it'll be a lot harder to loose weight over the long term. I personally was only in a rush since, I have type 2 diabetes and if you become less than 220 Pounds (100 Kg's) and you are of a young age... there is a chance, that you can actually loose your type 2 diabetes. + Fasting can help decrease or even get rid of some conditions/illnesses (to an extent) and now I don't have (mild) eczema anymore!

From this 7 Day Fast I had lost 15 Pounds (7 Kg's), but half of that was actually just water weight. (This happens with every 7 Days+ Fast.) So once I start breaking my Fast and eating vegetables again, I will become 7.5 Pounds (3.5 Kg's) heavier which is fine to me because weight loss needs to be realistic in order for it to work. I will keep dieting and eating healthy until I reach my goal, and I wish the person reading my comment that they will also have a healthy and happy life also. :)

technically your body's liver can convert proteins into carbohydrates when in the earlier stage of ketosis (obviously you run out of proteins if you go for longer then a week) Those proteins do not first come from muscle, they start with what is left in "the tank"/body. Because of this the body actually does not need any carbohydrates to survive since your liver can create the amounts needed. AGIN YOUR MUSCLES WILL NOT BREAK DOWN IF YOU GO FOR A DAY OR TWO WITHOUT EATING (EVEN LONGER IF YOU HAVE ALOT OF FAT. This is part of the reasons a keystone diet works so well provided you literally don't eat for weeks, you should be fine and your brain can get the remaining 25% of carbs from the liver provided before the fast you
1) had a big meal full of fats and proteins rich in micronutrients (the amount needed for your body to go for however long the fast will be.
2) optional but beneficial were/are overweight before the fast.
fun facts: their are studies that show your brain actually runs better on keystones. Ketogenic diets and intermittent fasting have been proven to drastically help people with neurological conditions like Alzheimer's. Going a day or two without eating skyrockets one's Human Growth Hormones above one thousand percent (look up the benefits of HGH if you don't know why that is outstanding) as long as you eat a big meal after the day or two you shouldn't have any negative effects provided the before the fast you fulfilled the prerequisite(s). Lastly binging in mild ketosis (not going Stop correcting multiple weeks without eating) has been shown to slow down the spreading of cancer since cancerous cells can only consume glucose and my even have a preventative effect.

Actually, once your body goes into the "fasted" state, which occurs after a few of hours of not eating, your body will begin to break down fat tissue into fatty acids for your tissues to use to spare glucose for the brain. Beta-Oxidation is the name of the process that utilizes fatty acids in tissues for energy in the fasted state. Your body will also break down muscle tissue for amino acids (alanine, glutamine) to send to the liver and kidney for a process known as gluconeogenesis. From this process, the body will create more glucose from these amino acids, along with many other compounds that can contribute to this process. The goal of your body is to maintain a steady blood glucose level because the brain demands it and is unable to use all other nutrients (like fatty acids) except for ketone bodies (which, yes, are derived from fatty acids). Without this steady level of blood glucose your brain would not be able to function properly and you would faint.

Ketogenesis starts at around 3 days I believe, (forming ketone bodies from fatty acids) but your brain doesn't fully adjust to it as a major source of nutrition until weeks of fasting, in which your body enters a new state called the "starved" state. Here, your brain adjusts to ketone bodies and stops demanding a high glucose blood level. This is beneficial because gluconeogenesis uses muscle proteins, and to constantly maintain that blood glucose without any food entering the body means constantly breaking down muscle tissue. If this were to continue, you would undergo multisystem organ failure and die. So, your brain switching to ketone bodies after some time is a good thing, because the brain begins to utilize fat stores for energy, just like the rest of the body is.

Eventually, when your fat stores run out, gluconeogenesis must occur again to keep the brain alive. You eventually cause organ failure because you are eating away at your muscle for the sake of glucose. And this isn't just skeletal muscle, but cardiac muscle and smooth muscle found in many of our organs and digestive tract.

During prolonged fasting the liver can and does synthisize glucose. The brain is not deprived of it. The limited endogenic production of glucose is low enough to not trigger much if any insulin responce and thes the glucose remains in the blood and is able to be utilized by neurons. In fact it is low levels of insulin which trigger the sythisis and higher levels that supres it. Ketones from fat  or muscular degeneration are used both by the brain and to fuel the cells of the body as they do not require insulin as a delivery device. There is no harm in fasting in fact for short periods occationally it can be good for ones health. Extended fasting obviously is dangerous and will often shorten ones lifespan considerably.

I've heard in my psychology class that if you don't eat much and you keep your stomach empty, you perform better. Now, not to say I believe that, but sometimes I fast here and now (fasting is when you take a day or more without food and drink nothing but water for both a spiritual reason or to cleanse your body) and I notice I have a more peaceful mind without eating. I also do focus better at school without eating (I never eat lunch when I went to school, I eat a snack when I come home or sometimes not at all) while all the other kids who eat feel sleepy. I never felt sleepy at once. I don't eat breakfast or lunch during school days. I notice when I was younger and I ate breakfast or lunch I felt sleepy at school, but ever since middle school, I didn't eat lunch or breakfast. Also, I don't have to go to the bathroom 24/7 at school when I don't eat. School lunch is horrific to eat anyways. But for kids or any adolescents out there, you should try it. I'm telling you, it works! I've been doing it since I was twelve, trust me, it's safe! You'll feel light-headed at first but after a while your body feels peaceful and lighter. No wonder many Christians (including me) do this sometimes!

I thought that of I didn't eat at all for an extended time then maybe I could lose even more than she did. The next day I woke up and didn't eat breakfast. That afternoon I ate one starburst, not a package with two, just one. When I got home from school I lost the record, I had a grilled cheese and nearly five servings of corn. Then for dinner I had nine ravioli's and one piece of garlic bread. I had about nine cups of water along with it. The next day I didn't eat breakfast or any lunch. After lunch I had a class at school and we cooked stir fry rice, I only ate a little, mainly because it was bland, this was surprising because normally we had delicious food. When I got home I had one cup of water and 82 pretzel sticks. Which was two servings. I then had stir fry rice for dinner. With two cups of water. The next day I ate one serving (41 pretzel sticks) when I got home from school and nine cups of water. The next day I ate gum. The following two days I only ate gum. I was sadly proud that I hadn't eaten for three days straight. I lost nearly ten pounds. Then I ate the next day. I had 41 pretzel sticks when I got home and then the vegtables my mother made for dinner with my own rice. She didn't question why because they were having chicken for dinner with corn, peas, and broccoli. I was a vegetarian, and still am. The next day I had a bowl of corn flakes with a little sugar for breakfast, then after school I had 41 pretzel sticks. Then the next three days I ate nothing at all. It went on, three days of 41 pretzel sticks the first with rice, 41 pretzel sticks with rice, 42 pretzel sticks with cereal and rice, no food, no food, no food, 41 pretzel sticks with rice, 41 pretzel sticks with rice, 41 pretzel sticks with rice and cereal, no food, no food, no food.

After two months of this I began to make more friends and I got more clothes and I felt happy.

After four months of this my grandma (step fathers side not that you need to know lololool sorry) did notice my absence of eating. She asked me questions and I began to eat more. For five months I ate breakfast which was always corn flakes with a little sugar with 41 pretzel sticks and some rice, corn flakes with a little sugar with 41 pretzel sticks and some rice, corn flakes with a little sugar with 41 pretzel sticks and some rice, no food, no food, no food. Of course I'm not counting the days where I had cooking class and we ate, I mostly only ate a little and threw the rest out. After those five months I began my original cycle, you know it. I did this for almost a year dropping a few pounds every week, I was soon way under weight and many people helped. There were about 15 people who generally helped me start eating normally again. I am still under weight and I'm trying to gain more to be healthy. Here's some advice: If you want to lose weight, do it the right way. It is more challenging but atleast if you do it the right way your body gets more healthy instead of making that go down.v

This is complete BS. Fasting is a healthy and natural process of cleansing the body that every animal instinctively does when ill or injured.  I myself have fasted 28 days on water alone and it was one of the best and most powerful experiences of my life.  I've seen people go as long as 49 days or 7 weeks and be perfectly fine.  You will feel like garbage and you will be low on energy but those are detox symptoms and symptoms caused by the switch over to ketosis.  Point being, fasting (or abstaining from food for a defined period) is not starving (abstaining from food indefinitely or eating and not getting the daily required calories to support life).  Fasting saves.

I have found from my experience that now that I am doing 23/1, which is 23 hours of fasting a day with one hour of eating, I require so much less food and even find myself not wanting to eat a lot and crap as well. If you keep your food low carb and  limit the body`s insulin response, the extra fat on your body will make up the difference in calories.

The longest I have fasted is 10 days and felt great. I know many who have fasted 21, 30 and even 40 days without food. The body does break down some muscle protein over a long fast, something like a couple pounds of lean muscle with a 30 day fast. It will exhaust the extra fat on the body before really going after the organs. After you get past around 72 hours or so, most people experience a loss of hunger and feel great for a long time. I would highly recommend short term and even long term fasting if you have a chance to really relax and take it easy.

Interesting...For what it is worth, I will share my recent experience:

I went 36 days on water only (I was trying for 40 days)...after the first few days it became fairly easy; by week three, I was having to rest a lot. By week four, I had to move slowly and deep-breath to keep from passing-out; about this time, I felt my body shifting its fuel source from (primarily) fat to muscle: catabolysis. In the 36th day in the middle of the night, my body woke me and basically "said" STOP THIS NOW!! I did so only because I had made myself accountable to those who love me. What had started as a spiritual effort (for people I love) devolved into a spiritual struggle where I really didn't care if I survived. By the end of it, I had lost over 40lbs (not counting fluid) and I had re-triggered the anorexia I had in my early adulthood. My fat was depleted enough that my body lost its curves and it was painful to sit on hard surfaces. Then as I gradually regained weight, I was scared I would overshoot my "dream weight," so I ended-up in several smaller fasts in the ensuing months. Now I am just a bit above my dream weight, gradually heading back down at a couple pounds a week. I still don't have a good relationship with food as a result of last year's fast, but I am obtaining some degree of balance. Spiritually, the outcomes I had hoped for did not occur, or rather not in with the speed and in the manner I would have liked; BUT I learned some very crucial things about "control" and "outcomes" that amount to a "spiritual breakthrough" which has enabled me to grow in some unexpected ways.

What happens when you stop eating??? first your body depletes its glycogen stores and your insulin level goes down. Next, when your glycogen is burned out your body begins to convert adipose tissue(FAT) into ketones. One of those ketones is Acetone. Yes, nail polish remover and paint thinner. The other ketones get sent to various tissues throughout your body and brain. The Acetone is converted to glucose which is converted to glycogen for use in your muscles as well as your brain and the rest of your body as well.You do not officially start to starve until your body drops BELOW 4% body fat. So if you have more than 4% Body fat, you will just keep burning fat until you go BELOW that 4% marker(Generally accepted BF level before starvation begins.) You can Literally survive longer if you are a fatty. I myself am one. Though LESS of one than 5 months ago. I have been fasting for 5 months. I eat a single 1500 calorie meal a day and I am down 96 pounds so far. There was a professional study performed in the 70's in England. They took a group Morbidly obese people. One of them was well over 400 pounds. He fasted for 379 days.He consumed NOTHING but water and vitamins. He ended up weighing 179 pounds as was in PERFECT health. They checked him again 2 years later after resuming meals and he only went up 10 pounds. So, in a nutshell, if you don't eat, you will be just fine. unless you are already close to REAL starvation levels.

I fasted twice for 28 days each time, once intentionally, once not.  I was very sick and had no desire to eat but drank a cup of water every 2 days and was in bed 22 hours at a time. I'm not sure most people can last over that though, as I myself felt death itself coming towards the ends of each time.  The second time was done intentionally because the military branch I was in said I needed to lose 50 pounds in 33 days because my wife, who was also military, would be sent to a remote location without me and I wouldn't be able to see her for 2 years.  I lost 58 pounds because she was worth dying for.  It's do-able.

You won't die from not eating for three weeks unless you have a medical condition and/or were underweight (no fat for the body to consume). The human body is built to preserve through periods of famine. Food is absolutely necessary, but the average person can live without it for a few weeks. An over weight person can live without food for months. People often blow "starving" (from an American perspective of not eating for a few days or weeks) out of proportion. Going through periods of fasting can actually be good for the body. I had a serious gut/bowel problem that I spent over 6K on for doctors to tell me I was healthy as a horse and nothing was wrong with me, even though I had severe diarrhea and was puking for two weeks at a time. It got to the point where I couldn't take it anymore and just stopped eating. I knew nothing about fasting at the time and didn't eat until I couldn't stand it anymore. I hadn't eaten food for a month (just drank water mixed with honey, tea, and coffee). I started out eating tiny portions of raw fruits and veggies, then went back to cooked food, then I went back to processed foods. NO MORE GUT/BOWEL PROBLEMS. I talked to my doctor about it and he said I probably had a bad colony of bacteria/viruses in my digestive tract and not eating for a month must have starved them out enough for the good bacteria in my body to kill it. Why wasn't I tested for bad bacteria and viruses when I was spending over 6k in the first place?  I would have lost my job and subsequently everything, if I didn't make the choice to stop eating. I probably would have died at dehydration at some point since the diarrhea and vomiting kept getting worse each month.

Quite a few mistakes here. For example, you always burn carbs and fat together. Burning fat in a healhy way actually requires carbs. The carbs/fat ratio depends on factors like your power output, the amount of glycogen that is left and how well trained your metabolism is.

A few years ago, one of my closest friends had an eating disorder where she barely ever ate any food…she just drank a lot of water and maybe ate a piece of fruit every once in a while.  I knew that this was really bad and that she needed help, but I never really understood what was actually going on in her body.  This video educated me on how not only her body and muscles were suffering from her eating disorder, but her own brain functioning was impaired as well.  I didn’t know that if a girl is not getting proper nutrition, her menstrual cycle will shut down because her body is trying to preserve energy.  If someone doesn’t eat for several weeks, they are also then being deprived of minerals and vitamins that are necessary for the body.  This video taught me that my friend, who was suffering from anorexia, had a high risk of having a heart attack because her heart was not getting proper nutrition to keep itself functioning the right way.  People who are living with an eating disorder that has to do with starving themselves and not getting the proper nutrition NEED to get help!  This is a serious problem that many people have around the world.  Someone who is not eating will experience many health issues…and could possibly even die.

I remember when I first started taking Adderall for my ADHD, I didn't eat a single thing for 3 days. I just didn't feel hungry, even though I knew I was supposed to be hungry. It was during the summer, and I don't have any friends, so I just stayed home and played videogames for the 3 days. The first day I didn't feel much of a difference. The second day, I still didn't feel hungry, but I felt a bit tired. By the third day, my thinking skills were doing terrible. I was trying to create a machine in minecraft, and I just couldn't figure out why some things weren't working correctly. The fourth day, I finally ate something as my mom started trying to force feed me.

For the next month, I only ate 1-2 meals a day. Now, a year later, I've lost 50lbs from me only eating 2 meals a day. I now eat 2-3 meals a day, and noticed that I can't eat big meals like I used to be able to do. I'm keeping a healthy weight of 165lbs ^.^

"Approximately" 795 million? You really think you have 3 digit accuracy on hunger, i.e. between 794.5 million and 795,499,999? Or even the nearest 5 million (792.5 million and 797,499,999)? On a given day or during a year? Was this number converted from metric people or what?  When Mount Everest was measured from a distance at 29,000 feet, the surveyors published a figure of 29,002 feet because they knew no one would believe that Everest was EXACTLY 29,000 feet high, but more importantly, they would have been seen as incompetent surveyors for apparently rounding to the nearest 1000 feet even if it was accurate to 3 or 4 or even 5 digits. We produce food for 12 billion people each year. We are 7. There is something very wrong in the way we try to live better. We are very inefficient. Which is what makes the market function... We really try to make the market function in the first place, not to solve hunger. Lands are being left useless because of agriculture explotation. Vertical farms could be interesting to look into.

Also, if we ate what the massive farm animals eat to grow so we can kill them later, we could produce even so much more food for humans. There is really not a quantity problem. It's just inefficiency.

They also burn food to keep it scarce and rise prices. I think every country should be forced legally to send that food to hungry people and stop destroying it. We need to understand what creates hunger in our global system before we try to solve it.

We tried that decades ago, then the military in those warring African countries stole the food stuffs for their soldiers and left their citizenry high and dry.

Unless the countries we want to help become stable it is essentially throwing good money after bad, as the old saying goes.  Helping people in countries which are stable is the better alternative, but yet those countries also have the resources to do that as well.  They are just so locked into their type of culture they don't believe they can surmount the problem, such as in India.

While your plans are admirable, they will never solve the problem as you perceive it to be.  Maybe you should read up on the "Stanford Crowding Problem" done with rats.  Starting with a large cage and all the food and water the animals would need, they allowed the breeding to continue unabated.  What they soon realized much to their horror, was that breeding went way down, there were fewer pregnancies.  Mother rats starting killing and sometimes eating their young, and fighting became the way of their life.

IE:  For those reasons alone I do not donate to causes which are generally found out after the fact to be scams.  We cannot save humanity nor the world from itself, and while trying to do so makes you feel a squishy inside, it accomplishes nothing until those societies wake up and think of their citizens as assets instead of liabilities.

I just went 72 hours with no food for the first time in my life.  I did allow myself to have tea and water.  Also took multivitamin each day.  During the first 24 hours I became really irritable and unhappy.  By 36 hours the irritability was gone and a kind of floating peaceful feeling replaced it.  Went about life as usual with no heavy workouts, felt somewhat lethargic but otherwise Ok.  I think we have evolved to go without food periodically.  Lost 7.5 lbs, two of which came back quickly, so more like +5 lbs permanent loss. I think everyone in rich countries should try fasting at least once, it may change your point of view or level of compassion towards those who have less.

As a type-1 diabetic of almost half-a-century, I've experienced countless times when my blood sugar, for various reasons, has not kept up with the amount of insulin I had injected that morning.
Imagine waking up in the middle of the night with this situation; one's mind is totally discombobulated with some weird scenario it has just been dreaming, and the brain itself is starving because of lack of glucose.
Amazingly enough, though I will be extremely out of it for the first several minutes, at some point (so far), the message "EAT SOMETHING, YOU !@#$ MORON!" will crash into my consciousness. That's when I grope around in the dark to take into my mouth's custody some nearby source of edibles.
Having a low blood sugar also affects one's control of his body; there's been times when I literally could not put one foot quickly in front of the other without falling flat on the hard concrete sidewalk.
I can't practice my guitar with a low blood sugar; my left hand is not able to press down on the strings on the neck. I have to stop practicing and eat something; which I am loathe to do because doing so breaks my momentum.

Wow...a huge amount of this is total bull. I have participated in religious fasts a number of times, often going as much as 3 weeks subsisting on only water, and I can say from personal experience, observation of others, and consultation with my doctor that going 3 days without food is not harmful in any way. In fact, there are a number of health benefits to be gained from going limited periods without food.

The feelings that one experiences on the first three days are similar to what is put in the video, but the speaker failed to mention that much of the pain one experiences during that time is due to the body purging itself of toxic substances that we absorb from eating unhealthy things. After 3 days, the stomach shuts down, making the body stop feeling hungry, and begins to break down FAT CELLS, NOT MUSCLES.

Regarding the immune system, the idea that it can degrade to the point of organ failure after as little as two weeks is ridiculous. Many studies have shown that fasting has a POSITIVE EFFECT ON IMMUNE HEALTH. The only people that can be harmed by reduced or temporarily halted food intake are those who already suffer from malnourishment or a vulnerable immune system.

It is a little bit more complicated than that.

 From a scientific point of view; if you form a settlement in a place where you do not have access to enough food or rather do not have enough food to satisfy the entire population, starvation will occur naturally. Countries that suffer from starvation are always way overpopulated for the environment they are in. Think about Africa. The lifestyle of it's inhabitants was fine tuned by evolution to fit the environment. However, when people from other civilizations came to invade, they brought their culture with them. People left their lifestyle that is suitable for smaller tribes and adopted one that their environment did not allow.

 From a social standpoint we, human's, want to save our kind; other humans. It makes sense at first glance to ship food from a more fertile soil to another. And we already do this, but nobody can just keep giving their food away without a cost. Nobody would agree to feed a foreign country at the expense of people much closer to them. Thus we are torn apart between the thoughts of "i must give my food to those who starve because i have more food than i already need anyway" and "i am working hard to bring food to the table, should i limit my own family for the sake of others?".

 You could be thinking; "People leave food on the table all the time around where i live, we clearly have enough food to save others". We do. Probably. We could ship all excess food on a country to another, perhaps enough to solve all problems of starvation for the people currently starving. "Currently" is the key word. There are a lot of beggars in Istanbul, most of them are children. Countries underdeveloped enough to face starvation are in an even worse condition than Istanbul, if you save a couple from starvation, they will create at least 3 more for YOU to feed, not them, because they cannot afford to feed them themselves. Thus, from a more philosophical standpoint, i cannot agree with the idea. Before people realize that it is not ok to create a child before you cannot even feed yourself properly, i will not help them. This is, from a social standpoint, almost as evil as wanting to kill these people, which is why it is not a popular opinion. But it is the hard truth of life.

 If you truly wish to help countries that face starvation, instead of increasing the amount of people that will starve, you need to sacrifice a lot more than just a bit of food. The entire world needs to adopt a different system that is based on keeping everything homogeneous, from wealth to health... We are already seeing a similar system fail in Europe with the current crisis regarding Greece.

I was fed up with my excess weight, exercise didn't change much, so last year i thought to myself the same question: what if I don't eat a thing and start building a clean diet and make it a lifestyle. I learnt the fact of losing muscle, bones, etc. so I what if I only eat protein, vitamins and minerals? it'd help sustaining muscles (not totally, but much better than starving), so I started that diet and at the same time I was educating myself about nutrition. I've learnt that my diet was very similar to atkins diet and I was on ketosis mode. My mood has changed a bit and I needed a bit of fibre in my diet since going to loo was happening much less than the normal time, I also needed to alkalise my blood, so added the green veggies next to my boiled eggs, whey, yoghurt, cheese, etc. diet. It worked and I lost 3 stones (incl. glycogen/water weight) within few months. So now I'm doing it again this year, slower and added more exercise to balance it out
